title: Encroachment of Baidyanath Dham Guthi Land in Achham
description:
This case concerns the alleged encroachment of a large tract of land belonging to the Baidyanath Dham Guthi, a historically significant religious trust in Achham District, Nepal. A government-appointed commission and the Guthi Sansthan (Guthi Corporation) have concluded that 862 Ropani and 3 Paisa (approximately 106.5 acres) of land have been illegally occupied by 171 families.

The Guthi's claim dates back to a royal decree (Lalmohar) issued by King Rana Bahadur Shah in approximately 1795 AD (1852 BS), which granted it around one thousand ropani of land. A subsequent survey in 1929 AD (1986 BS) also recorded this ownership. However, currently, only 137 ropani are officially registered in the Guthi's name.

The conflict escalated when the Guthi Sansthan decided to reclaim the land. The 171 families residing on the disputed plots, organized under the 'Baidyanath Guthi Land Victims Struggle Committee', launched protests, including padlocking the temple. These residents possess land ownership certificates (Lalpurja) and claim they are the rightful owners, having inherited the land from their ancestors. They allege a conspiracy to make them landless, arguing that the note 'Baidyanath Dham Guthi' on their pre-2002 certificates is being used to unjustly usurp their private property.
unverified_info:
The following information requires further investigation:

  • Government Commission Report: A report from the 'Commission to Investigate Government, Public, and Guthi Land' confirming the encroachment was submitted to then-Prime Minister K.P. Sharma Oli around 2020. However, this report has not been made public, so its full findings, evidence, and recommendations are unknown.
  • Involvement of CIAA: There is no specific public record of the Commission for the Investigation of Abuse of Authority (CIAA) launching a formal investigation into this particular case of land encroachment at Baidyanath Dham.
key_allegations: Illegal encroachment of 862 ropani and 3 paisa of land belonging to the Baidyanath Dham Guthi.
Illegal settlement and occupation by 171 families on protected Guthi land.
Counter-allegation by residents that their private land is being usurped by authorities using forged or manipulated historical documents.
alleged_entities: 171 families residing on disputed land in Sanfebagar Municipality and Chaurpati Rural Municipality

timeline.title: Royal Decree Grants Land to Guthi
timeline.description: King Rana Bahadur Shah issues a royal decree (Lalmohar) granting approximately 1,000 ropani of land and three villages to the Baidyanath Dham Guthi. This date is an approximation based on the year 1852 BS.

timeline.title: Land Survey Confirms Guthi Ownership
timeline.description: A land survey conducted in approximately 1929 AD (1986 BS) officially records one thousand ropani of land in the name of the Baidyanath temple.

timeline.title: Issuance of Disputed Land Certificates
timeline.description: Land ownership certificates (Lalpurja) are issued to local individuals for plots on the Guthi land. The certificates bear the individual's name but also have 'Baidyanath Dham Guthi' written at the top. This occurred prior to 2058 BS (2002 AD).

timeline.title: Government Commission Confirms Encroachment
timeline.description: The 'Commission to Investigate Government, Public, and Guthi Land' conducts an investigation around 2077 BS (2020 AD) and submits a report to the Prime Minister's office, confirming that 862 ropani of the Guthi's land has been encroached upon.

timeline.title: Guthi Sansthan Rules Land Belongs to Guthi
timeline.description: The central office of the Guthi Sansthan in Kathmandu formally decides that the disputed land belongs to the Baidyanath Dham Guthi, not the individuals possessing land certificates. The exact date in 2022 is not specified.

timeline.title: Local Residents Launch Protests
timeline.description: In response to the Guthi Sansthan's decision to reclaim the land, local residents under the 'Baidyanath Guthi Land Victims Struggle Committee' launch protests, accusing the government of trying to render them landless.
